user_question: Among all 12 references in this report, how many are from its own research center?

knowledge_chain.query: reference list from the report including affiliations or research center origins
knowledge_chain.raw_result:
The report references multiple sources and research entities, primarily centered around data and analyses conducted by the Pew Research Center. The following is a list of the referenced documents and their affiliations or research center origins, as explicitly stated in the provided context:

- [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf — This is the primary report titled “Latinos Increasingly Confident in Personal Finances, See Better Economic Times Ahead,” published by the Pew Research Center in 2016. All charts, tables, and survey data cited originate from this report, which is based on the National Survey of Latinos conducted in 2015 and other prior surveys.

Additional cited works from the report’s reference list include:

- Blumberg, Stephen J. and Julian V. Luke. 2016. “Wireless Substitution: Early Release of Estimates From the National Health Interview Survey, July-December 2015.” Hyattsville, Md.: National Center for Health Statistics, May.  
- DeNavas-Walt, Carmen and Bernadette D. Proctor. 2015. “Income and Poverty in the United States: 2014.” Washington, D.C.: U.S. Census Bureau, September.  
- Kochhar, Rakesh. 2014. “Latino Jobs Growth Driven by U.S. Born: Immigrants No Longer the Majority of Hispanic Workers.” Washington, D.C.: Pew Research Center, June.  
- Kochhar, Rakesh and Richard Fry. 2014. “Wealth inequality has widened along racial, ethnic lines since end of the Great Recession.” Washington, D.C.: Pew Research Center, December.  
- Kochhar, Rakesh, Richard Fry and Paul Taylor. 2011. “Wealth Gaps Rise to Record Highs Between Whites, Blacks, Hispanics.” Washington, D.C.: Pew Research Center, July.  
- Lopez, Mark Hugo, Ana Gonzalez-Barrera and Jens Manuel Krogstad. 2014. “Latino Support for Democrats Falls, but Democratic Advantage Remains.” Washington, D.C.: Pew Research Center, October.  
- National Bureau of Economic Research. 2010. “US Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions.” Cambridge, Mass.: National Bureau of Economic Research, September.  
- Pew Research Center. 2015. “As Election Year Nears, Public Sees Mixed Economic Picture: Less economic optimism, but fewer feel like they’re ‘falling behind.’” Washington, D.C.: December.  
- Pew Research Center. 2014. “Most See Inequality Growing, but Partisans Differ Over Solutions.” Washington, D.C.: January.  
- Pew Research Center. 2009. “Between Two Worlds: How Young Latinos Come of Age in America.” Washington, D.C.: December.  
- Stepler, Renee and Anna Brown. 2016. “Statistical Portrait of Hispanics in the United States.” Washington, D.C.: Pew Research Center, April.  
- Weeks, Matt. 2014. “Minorities energize U.S. consumer market, according to UGA Multicultural Economy report.” Athens, GA: Selig Center for Economic Growth, September.

All primary data and visualizations in the report are derived from Pew Research Center surveys and analyses, with supporting data from the U.S. Census Bureau, Bureau of Labor Statistics, National Health Interview Survey, and other authoritative sources.

### References

- [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf
- Blumberg, Stephen J. and Julian V. Luke. 2016. “Wireless Substitution: Early Release of Estimates From the National Health Interview Survey, July-December 2015.”
- DeNavas-Walt, Carmen and Bernadette D. Proctor. 2015. “Income and Poverty in the United States: 2014.”
- Kochhar, Rakesh. 2014. “Latino Jobs Growth Driven by U.S. Born: Immigrants No Longer the Majority of Hispanic Workers.”
- Kochhar, Rakesh and Richard Fry. 2014. “Wealth inequality has widened along racial, ethnic lines since end of the Great Recession.”
- Kochhar, Rakesh, Richard Fry and Paul Taylor. 2011. “Wealth Gaps Rise to Record Highs Between Whites, Blacks, Hispanics.”
- Lopez, Mark Hugo, Ana Gonzalez-Barrera and Jens Manuel Krogstad. 2014. “Latino Support for Democrats Falls, but Democratic Advantage Remains.”
- National Bureau of Economic Research. 2010. “US Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions.”
- Pew Research Center. 2015. “As Election Year Nears, Public Sees Mixed Economic Picture: Less economic optimism, but fewer feel like they’re ‘falling behind.’”
- Pew Research Center. 2014. “Most See Inequality Growing, but Partisans Differ Over Solutions.”
- Pew Research Center. 2009. “Between Two Worlds: How Young Latinos Come of Age in America.”
- Stepler, Renee and Anna Brown. 2016. “Statistical Portrait of Hispanics in the United States.”
- Weeks, Matt. 2014. “Minorities energize U.S. consumer market, according to UGA Multicultural Economy report.”
knowledge_chain.summary: Among the 12 references in the report, five are from the Pew Research Center. These include the primary report [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf and four additional publications authored by Pew Research Center researchers in 2009, 2014, 2015, and 2016.
